intro: Bahamas International Business Companies (IBCs) are used as vehicles to open bank accounts and to render import and export services, as well as a variety of other services for international firms and nonresident natural persons. The Bahamas meet all the requirements in terms of expeditiousness, cost-effectiveness and efficiency for the incorporation of IBCs, which are known for their versatility, low costs and simple administration. They are regulated by the International Business Companies Act, 2000 (as amended up until 2011).
highlights: No taxes levied on international and banking transactions.
No capital gains, income or other kinds of taxes.
social: Location: chain of islands in the North Atlantic Ocean, 50 miles southeast of Florida, (U.S.A.), northeast of Cuba
Area: 700 islands, cays, and islets comprising 13,880 sq km. Most Bahamians live in two major urban centres: Nassau and Freeport
Government: Parliamentary Democracy. Member of the British Commonwealth recognizing Queen Elizabeth II as head of state
Legal Tender: Bahamian dollar, which is on a par with the U.S. dollar
Industry: Tourism, financial services and small industries
